report_title: Industry Report on Hard Seltzer Production
executive_summary: The hard seltzer industry's revenue is forecasted to surge and progress steadily through 2024, continuing to inch up until 2029 due to changing consumer preferences for low-calorie, low-alcohol beverages. Revenue is anticipated to expand at a CAGR of 9.6% over the five years to 2024 to reach $2.5 billion. Profit will inch down to 3.6% in 2024 due to competitive forces.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Hard Seltzer Revolution Involves a Meteoric Swell
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Hard seltzer has become mainstream, with the industry booming over the five years to 2024. White Claw burst onto the scene in 2016 and quickly became the leading player. The expansion has also been influenced by boosted demand from bars and nightclubs.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Winning Over Millennials: Successful Internet Marketing
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Hard seltzer has presented a healthier alternative to beer, gaining popularity through strategic use of social media influencers and viral marketing, especially among millennials and older Gen Z.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Hard Seltzer Demand Surged Amid COVID-19 Lockdowns
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: During the COVID-19 lockdowns in 2020, hard seltzer producers saw further growth as alcohol was viewed as a stress coping mechanism, and hard seltzer was a healthier, cheaper alternative.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Hard Seltzer Production is Set to Skyrocket
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Hard seltzer consumption is anticipated to continue growing as it is viewed as a healthier alternative by young consumers. The ease of production makes it viable for craft breweries, potentially driving enterprise growth.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Innovation and Diversification Fuel the Industry
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As competition intensifies, hard seltzer producers will explore innovative flavors and healthier additives to make their products stand out and capture consumer curiosity and market share.

industry_definition: Operators in the Hard Seltzer Production industry produce beverages containing alcohol and carbonated water, offering a wide range of products with various recipes and flavors.
key_trends: Hard seltzer producers have seen substantial growth in recent years, with an expected steady expansion in the near future driven by changing consumer preferences towards low-calorie, low-alcohol beverages.
The expansion is also influenced by boosted demand from bars and nightclubs, which offer hard seltzer as a lighter alternative.

Hard seltzer producers are regulated by the Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (TTB) in the US, which ensures compliance with federal standards. Producers typically need both federal and state permits to operate legally.
The TTB provides resources to assist hard seltzer producers with compliance. Trade groups like the American Craft Spirits Association also support the industry.
Hard seltzers with 5-6.9% alcohol content are the most popular, led by brands like White Claw, Truly and Natty Light.
Hard seltzers with 1-4.9% and 7.0%+ alcohol content are the next most popular categories, driven by brands like Bon and Viv, Smirnoff, Henry's and lesser-known brands.

Liquor stores dominate sales, followed by convenience stores, restaurants, supermarkets and clubs. Factors contributing to popularity include variety, price, convenience, meal pairing and nutritional content.

The market faces fierce competition with numerous established and emerging brands, with major brewers like Anheuser-Busch constantly innovating and smaller niche brands differentiating with unique flavors or local/craft trends.
Challenges include market saturation and changing consumer preferences.

Financial performance shows relatively steady profit from 2019 to 2024, indicating a preference shift towards low-calorie, flavor-varied alcohol and enhancing the industry's reputation as a reliable segment.
Moderately high purchase costs for raw materials and equipment through 2024 may lead to industry consolidation as smaller producers struggle financially.

market_segmentation.segment: Liquor Stores are the Domestic Dominator
market_segmentation.segment_description: Liquor stores are the leading market segment for hard seltzers, capturing the most impressive share. The extensive variety offered and the opportunity to explore new brands and flavors contribute to customer attraction. Also, the age restriction in these establishments ensures a qualified buyer base for an alcoholic product like hard seltzers.

market_segmentation.segment: Convenience Stores Offer Speedy Seltzers On-The-Go
market_segmentation.segment_description: Convenience stores rank second, providing a quick grab & go option for hard seltzer enthusiasts. Favorable pricing and easy accessibility round the clock make them a top choice among consumers. Offering chilled hard seltzers directly from the fridge to the buyer is a unique selling proposition, promoting impulse buys.

market_segmentation.segment: Hard Seltzers are Joining the Menu at Many Restaurants
market_segmentation.segment_description: Restaurants are next on the list, incorporating hard seltzers into their drink menus. Customers appreciate the chance to pair their favorite meals with a light, refreshing option like hard seltzers.

market_segmentation.segment: Supermarkets, Grocery Stores and Drug Stores are Becoming Popular Outlets
market_segmentation.segment_description: The attraction here lies in the ability to make a one-stop-shop for all household items, including alcoholic beverages. Consumer trends highlight the purchase of hard seltzers during regular grocery shopping as being highly convenient. Also, these stores often offer regular discounts or loyalty points, influencing purchase decisions.

market_segmentation.segment: Clubs are the Next Big Party Craze
market_segmentation.segment_description: While club sales are lower compared with the aforementioned places, hard seltzers are starting to make a mark here. Some patrons are switching from high sugar cocktail options to healthier alternatives, making seltzers the new club favorites.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Power Packing 5-6.9% ABV Rules the Roost
products_and_services.product_description: The 5-6.9% hard seltzers segment is the most popular among consumers. Brands like White Claw, Truly and Natty Light are pioneers in this segment, garnering significant attention.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Refreshingly Crisp 1-4.9% Hard Seltzers are the Second Favorites
products_and_services.product_description: The 1-4.9% ABV hard seltzers segment is the next most popular, following behind 5-6.9% offerings. Brands like Bon and Viv, Smirnoff and Henry's drive this segment.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Heavy Hitters: Bold and Buzzworthy, 7.0%+ Hard Seltzers Make a Statement
products_and_services.product_description: The 7.0%+ ABV hard seltzers segment comes last in terms of popularity. Despite being less popular, it caters to a niche market of consumers who prefer stronger alcoholic content.

FAQs.question: How do shifts in consumer preferences toward things like increased health consciousness affect your business performance?
FAQs.answer: Shifts towards health consciousness can boost business performance for hard seltzer producers, since their products are typically lower in calories and sugar. This consumer preference might lead to an increase in demand for hard seltzers.

FAQs.question: How does your company maintain a competitive edge?
FAQs.answer: Competition in the Hard Seltzer Production industry tends to be linked to both price and reputation.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: Hard seltzer producers might face volatility in their input prices due to factors like fluctuations in the prices of raw materials like sugar, fruits, packing materials and shipping costs.

FAQs.question: How does the size of your company affect its profitability and growth potential?
FAQs.answer: Although the industry is highly fragmented, there are still several operators that command significant shares of the industry.

FAQs.question: Does your company use RFID to optimize inventory management and improve efficiency?
FAQs.answer: Handheld radio-frequency identification (RFID) systems have recently become the industry's standard in scanning and tracking inventory, while manual and electric pallet jacks continue to be perennial necessities for transporting bulk quantities of hard seltzer products between distribution centers.

FAQs.question: Have automation and computerization enabled you to cut labor costs?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators use software to track production statistics. Industry operators are increasing their use of technology to increase efficiencies.

FAQs.question: How does your company monitor potential changes to the regulatory environment?
FAQs.answer: The Hard Seltzer Production industry is highly regulated, with laws covering everything from labeling to dry county laws. It is crucial that operators stay up to date with industry regulations.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all relevant health and safety requirements are met?
FAQs.answer: Operators must comply with a wide range of health and safety requirements, from employee regulations set by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration to beverage handling laws set by the Food and Drug Administration.

FAQs.question: What immediate financial challenges are you likely to face in the next year?
FAQs.answer: The industry's primary capital expenditures go toward the use and replacement of buildings, trucking fleet and equipment.

FAQs.question: How has input price volatility affected your purchase costs and selling prices over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: The price of diesel has a significant affect on industry operators, as they use trucks to distribute their product, and gas is a relatively significant expense.

FAQs.question: Are you able to sell your products in various locations? Do you have plans to expand into new locations?
FAQs.answer: Most hard seltzer is sold in grocery stores and other off-premise locations, but industry operators can benefit from selling their products in bars, restaurants and other on-premise markets.

FAQs.question: How do you market your product to consumers? What kind of customer base does your company have?
FAQs.answer: Hard seltzer is typically a homogeneous product, but most customers have a specific brand that they prefer over others.

FAQs.question: How are you able to capitalize on economies of scale? Do you have any plans to increase the size of your business?
FAQs.answer: The most successful companies in the industry are large operators with the resources to quickly produce a large supply of hard seltzer.

FAQs.question: How much business do you do with bars and nightclubs? Do you plan to work with more bars given high general demand?
FAQs.answer: While most hard seltzer sales come from off-premise markets, such as grocery stores, bars represent a significant market for industry operators.

FAQs.question: Do you track sugar and sweetener consumption? Have you shifted to producing products for more health-conscious consumers?
FAQs.answer: A decline in sugar consumption signals greater demand for low-calorie products such as hard seltzer.

FAQs.question: Are there any products that are particularly popular? Do you track alcohol consumption?
FAQs.answer: When expenditure on alcohol grows, so does demand for hard seltzer.
